liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: CNN has cited sources saying the former marine, Daniel Penny, is expected to be charged with manslaughter today. He put a man in a chokehold that killed him on the New York City subway. There have been protests across the city since footage of Jordan Neely being restrained emerged.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former US marine to be charged with manslaughter in choking death on subway

children.content: CNN has cited sources saying the former marine, Daniel Penny, is expected to be charged with manslaughter today.
He put a man in a chokehold that killed him on the New York City subway.
There have been protests across the city since footage of Jordan Neely being restrained emerged.
New York police officers respond to the scene where a fight was reported on a subway train, Monday, May 1.
(AP: Paul martinka)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: WOOHOO! Australia has made it to the final of the Eurovision Song Contest. Australia is represented this year by Perth-based metal-synth band Voyager. The global music spectacle is being held in the British city Liverpool, in place of last year's winner Ukraine. Some of the most competitive countries, including France, Italy, and Israel, have all already secured their spot in this weekend's grand final. It's Australia's final shot at Eurovision for now, as the deal with the European Broadcasting Union is up for renewal this year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia reaches the Eurovision finals!

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Twitter boss Elon Musk says he's found a replacement CEO for the social media platform, who will be starting in about six weeks. Musk hasn't named the candidate, but says he'll take on the roles of executive chair and chief technology officer. Tesla shares jumped 2.4 per cent when Musk shared the news. Critics say Musk's tenure as chief executive has sullied the platform's integrity, and its regulation has been grossly undermined by thousands of job cuts.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Musk says Twitter has found its next CEO

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's been huge debate on this topic since Tuesday night's Commonwealth budget. A lot of economists, such as Steven Hamilton and Chris Richardson, argue measures to relieve the cost of living such as power bill subsidies will leave households with more money to spend and thus be inflationary, at least to some degree. But the Commonwealth Bank's head of Australian economics Gareth Aird, who was recently in the minority of market economists who successfully forecast the RBA's May rate hike, believes the budget may even help bring down inflation, as the Treasurer has claimed. "The Government's Energy Price Relief Plan is expected to subtract 0.75ppts [percentage points] from headline inflation in 2023/24. Medicare bulk billing incentives along with childcare subsidies will also put downward pressure directly on measured inflation. "It can be argued that these packages free up some consumer cash flow to spend on other goods and services. And therefore the second round impacts of the package are inflationary. But we don't subscribe to that view. "Inflation expectations are a driver of inflation over the medium term. And inflation expectation can be heavily influenced by actual inflation. Lowering measured inflation in the short run at a time when there remains lingering concerns around inflation psychology makes a lot of sense. It is both smart politics and smart economics. "Many wage agreements and price outcomes are set with the level of actual inflation in mind. If measured inflation recedes more quickly it can dampen down the consumer and business expectation of entrenching price rises – a welcome outcome." My colleague Kate Ainsworth had a comprehensive article earlier this week featuring both sides of the debate.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will the budget add to inflation? No says CBA

featuredLink.title: Budget heightens risk for the Reserve Bank to raise interest rates 'at least once' in coming months

children.content: There's been huge debate on this topic since Tuesday night's Commonwealth budget.
A lot of economists, such as
Steven Hamilton and Chris Richardson
, argue measures to relieve the cost of living such as power bill subsidies will leave households with more money to spend and thus be inflationary, at least to some degree.

document.title: Could the budget fuel further interest rate rises?

titleAlt.lg: Could the budget fuel further interest rate rises?
titleAlt.md: Could the budget fuel further interest rate rises?
titleAlt.sm: Could the budget fuel further interest rate rises?

children.content: But the
Commonwealth Bank's head of Australian economics Gareth Aird
, who was recently in the minority of market economists who successfully forecast the RBA's May rate hike, believes the budget may even help bring down inflation, as the Treasurer has claimed.

props.alt: CBA's head of Australian economics Gareth Aird

children.content: CBA's head of Australian economics Gareth Aird
(ABC News: John Gunn)

"The Government's Energy Price Relief Plan is expected to subtract 0.75ppts [percentage points] from headline inflation in 2023/24. Medicare bulk billing incentives along with childcare subsidies will also put downward pressure directly on measured inflation.

"It can be argued that these packages free up some consumer cash flow to spend on other goods and services. And therefore the second round impacts of the package are inflationary. But we don't subscribe to that view.
"Inflation expectations are a driver of inflation over the medium term. And inflation expectation can be heavily influenced by actual inflation.
Lowering measured inflation in the short run at a time when there remains lingering concerns around inflation psychology makes a lot of sense. It is both smart politics and smart economics.

"Many wage agreements and price outcomes are set with the level of actual inflation in mind. If measured inflation recedes more quickly it can dampen down the consumer and business expectation of entrenching price rises – a welcome outcome."
My colleague
Kate Ainsworth
had a comprehensive article earlier this week featuring both sides of the debate.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Just before the Bank of England busied itself with another rate rise, the RBA released a raft of internal research due to a Freedom of Information request. The most interesting was some modelling done by a senior analyst in the Economic Analysis Department in September last year that found Australia had between a 50 to 80% chance of recession if the Reserve Bank was successful in returning inflation below 3% by late-2024. If the bank was a bit slower in lowering inflation, leaving it just above the target band by the end of 2024, recession risk could be as low as 30 per cent, depending which model was used. But that is still much higher than the 5 per cent chance of recession Australia would normally have according to recent history, and 13 per cent odds over a longer historical period. I spoke to Kath Robinson about it on The Business last night. There was some other research, from earlier this year, that modelled the effects of different interest rate paths on inflation and unemployment. Some of those models looked at a cash rate as high as 4.8 per cent, but the RBA's most recent forecasts and actions make it look very unlikely it will push rates that far. You can read the full article I wrote yesterday here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ICYMI: RBA forecasts up to 80 per cent recession risk

featuredLink.title: RBA research puts Australian recession risk at up to 80 per cent by 2024

The most interesting was some modelling done by a senior analyst in the Economic Analysis Department in September last year that found
Australia had between a 50 to 80% chance of recession if the Reserve Bank was successful in returning inflation below 3% by late-2024
If the bank was a bit slower in lowering inflation
, leaving it just above the target band by the end of 2024,
recession risk could be as low as 30 per cent
, depending which model was used.
But that is still much higher than the 5 per cent chance of recession Australia would normally have according to recent history, and 13 per cent odds over a longer historical period.
I spoke to
Kath Robinson
about it on
The Business
last night.
There was some other research, from earlier this year, that modelled the effects of different interest rate paths on inflation and unemployment.
Some of those models looked at a cash rate as high as 4.8 per cent
, but the RBA's most recent forecasts and actions make it look very unlikely it will push rates that far.
You can read the full article I wrote yesterday here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Bank of England has kept raising interest rates, with another 0.25 of a percentage point move. " The BoE raised the bank rate 25bp to 4.50%, as was widely expected, the 7-2 vote (two dovish dissenters voting for no change) also as expected. "A more favourable economic outcome of low growth rather than recession and tight labour market conditions were noted. "Guidance remained hawkish – if high inflation persists, they will tighten policy further ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bank of England raises rates by majority vote

children.content: The

, as was widely expected, the 7-2 vote (two dovish dissenters voting for no change) also as expected.
"A more favourable economic outcome of low growth rather than recession and tight labour market conditions were noted.
"Guidance remained hawkish –
if high inflation persists, they will tighten policy further
